metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Keeper of Bharati Press

facts.text: Respondent was the keeper of Bharati Press at Purulia.
Pamphlet under the heading 'Sangram' printed at Bharati Press and circulated in Purulia, district of Manbhum.
Government of Bihar considered pamphlet contained objectionable matter under section 4(1) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, XXIII of 1931.
Government required press to furnish security of Rs. 2,000 under section 3(3) by 19th September 1949.
On 26th September 1949, respondent applied to High Court of Patna under section 23 to set aside the order.

High Court Special Bench (Shearer, Ramaswami and Sarjoo Prosad JJ.) in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 220 of 1949 allowed application by majority (Sarjoo Prosad J. with Ramaswami J.), Shearer J. dissented.
High Court held pamphlet came within mischief of Act but section 4(1)(a) repugnant to Article 19(1) and void under Article 13.
Appeal to Supreme Court under Articles 132(1) and 134(1)(c) of Constitution.
Pamphlet written in high-flown Bengali, contains demagogic claptrap, abstract propositions, poetic flourish; no specific oppression or cause mentioned; no connection to any agitation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the pamphlet contained words or signs or visible representations of the nature described in section 4(1) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act.
Whether provisions of section 4(1)(a) of the Act are inconsistent with Article 19(1) of the Constitution and void under Article 13.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pamphlet falls within section 4(1)(a) as it contemplates bloody revolution, incites violence; certain passages support this.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(1)(a) Indian Press Emergency Powers Act; Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 4(1)(a) not repugnant to Constitution; Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan do not apply as they concern broader public order, not specific incitement to violence undermining State security.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 19(2); Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras; Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi

petitioner_arguments.text: Amendment to Article 19(2) retrospective, not violative of Article 20.

respondent_arguments.text: Leaflet does not contain words inciting murder or cognizable offences involving violence under section 4(1)(a).
Pamphlet contains empty slogans, figurative language, no tendency to excite; to be read as whole, not isolated passages.
Amendment to Article 19(2) repugnant to Article 20 as it declares act offence retrospectively.

court_reasoning.text: Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan concern broader public order restrictions, not specific incitement to violence like section 4(1)(a) which undermines State security and falls within Article 19(2).
Pamphlet is high-flown Bengali demagogic claptrap, abstract, no specific cause or oppression; no evidence of local agitation; read as whole, no tendency to incite violence among educated readers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pamphlet does not fall within section 4(1)(a).

court_reasoning.text: Document to be considered as whole, in fair spirit; stock phrases of demagogues have lost sting; no proof of exceptional circumstances.
Amendment to Article 19(2) does not violate Article 20; no retrospective criminalisation.

holdings.text: Section 4(1)(a) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act is not repugnant to Article 19(1)(a) and is valid under Article 19(2).
Pamphlet does not contain matter inciting or encouraging commission of murder or cognizable offence involving violence under section 4(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Concerns broader public order restrictions under Madras Act, not specific incitement to violence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Romesh Thapar, does not compel invalidity of section 4(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar
precedents_cited.relevance: Extravagant language in pamphlets does not excite violence in normal circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Government
precedents_cited.relevance: Poem had consistent purpose to incite labourers; unlike abstract pamphlet here.
Words create no impression on reasonable reader; principle applies to section 4(1)(a).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for security demand and challenge; section 4(1)(a) held constitutional but not attracted.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 4(1)(a) within Article 19(2) restrictions; High Court treated as Article 226 petition.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as High Court erred in holding section 4(1)(a) unconstitutional but correctly (though for wrong reason) set aside security order since pamphlet does not fall within the section; no order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: speeches or expressions... which incite to or encourage the commission of violent crimes, such as murder, cannot but be matters which would undermine the security of the State and come within the ambit of a law sanctioned by article 19(2).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the pamphlet contains merely empty slogans, carrying no particular meaning except some amount of figurative expression or language borrowed at random from various authors with a touch of poetic flourish.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason pamphlet does not incite violence.

key_quotes.text: if a person were to go on inciting murder... he would be free to do so with impunity... This would be so, because such speech... would fall neither under libel nor slander nor defamation...
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court observation critiqued as misunderstanding Supreme Court precedents.
